S5.T2.caption: Table 2: Test accuracy with ResNet-18 network after 100 communication rounds.
S5.T2.table:
Fed-SGD Adp-Fed Fed-AMS Fed-LAMB Mime Mime-LAMB
CIFAR-10 90.75 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.48 91.57 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.38 90.93 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.22 92.44 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.53 90.94 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.13 92.00 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.21
TinyImageNet 67.58 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.21 74.17 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.43 64.86 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.83 76.00 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.26 67.82 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.24 73.46 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.25
references: In Figure 4, we present the results on CIFAR-10 and TinyImageNet datasets trained by ResNet-18. When training these two models, we decrease the learning rate to 1/101101/10 at the 30-th and 70-th communication round. From Figure 4, we can draw similar conclusion as before: the proposed Fed-LAMB is the best method in terms of both convergence speed and generalization accuracy. In particular, on TinyImageNet, we see that Fed-LAMB has a significant advantage over all three baselines. Although Adp-Fed performs better than Fed-SGD and Fed-AMS, it is considerably worse than Fed-LAMB. We report the test accuracy at the end of training in Table 2. Fed-LAMB achieves the highest accuracy on both datasets. Mime-LAMB also substantially improves Mime.

A1.T3.caption: Table 3: Search grids of the learning rate.
references: In our empirical study, we tune the learning rate of each algorithm carefully such that the best performance is achieved. The search grids in all our experiments are provided in Table 3.
